description: Master Vim editor with comprehensive exercises - from basics to advanced text editing wizardry

tasks.title: Starting Vim
tasks.description: Open Vim without any file. What command starts the Vim editor?
hints: Just type 'vim' to start the editor
You'll see the intro screen with tildes (~)
tasks.explanation: The 'vim' command starts the Vim editor. When started without a filename, you'll see the intro screen.

tasks.title: Open Specific File
tasks.description: Open the file 'hello.txt' in Vim. How do you open a specific file?
hints: Provide the filename as an argument to vim
tasks.explanation: To open a specific file in Vim, pass the filename as an argument: 'vim filename.txt'

tasks.title: Open Multiple Files
tasks.description: Open three files at once: 'file1.txt', 'file2.txt', and 'file3.txt'. How do you open multiple files?
hints: List multiple filenames separated by spaces
Vim will open them in separate buffers
tasks.explanation: You can open multiple files by listing them: 'vim file1.txt file2.txt file3.txt'. Each opens in a separate buffer.

tasks.title: Vim with Horizontal Windows
tasks.description: Open Vim with 3 horizontal split windows. What option creates horizontal splits?
hints: Use the -o option followed by the number
tasks.explanation: The '-o' option followed by a number creates that many horizontal split windows.

tasks.title: Vim with Vertical Windows
tasks.description: Open Vim with 2 vertical split windows. What option creates vertical splits?
hints: Use the -O option (capital O) followed by the number
tasks.explanation: The '-O' (capital O) option followed by a number creates that many vertical split windows.

tasks.title: Execute Command on Startup
tasks.description: Open 'config.txt' and immediately execute the Vim command ':set number' to show line numbers. How do you execute commands on startup?
hints: Use the + option followed by the command in quotes
tasks.explanation: The '+command' option executes a Vim command immediately after opening the file.

tasks.title: Basic Character Movement - Left
tasks.description: In Vim normal mode, which key moves the cursor one character to the left?
hints: It's one of the home row keys
Think of 'h' as going backwards in the alphabet
tasks.explanation: The 'h' key moves the cursor one character to the left in normal mode.

tasks.title: Basic Character Movement - Down
tasks.description: In Vim normal mode, which key moves the cursor down one line?
hints: It's a home row key that looks like it points down
The key 'j' has a descender that goes down
tasks.explanation: The 'j' key moves the cursor down one line. The letter 'j' has a descender, like going down.

tasks.title: Basic Character Movement - Up
tasks.description: In Vim normal mode, which key moves the cursor up one line?
tasks.explanation: The 'k' key moves the cursor up one line in normal mode.

tasks.title: Basic Character Movement - Right
tasks.description: In Vim normal mode, which key moves the cursor one character to the right?
hints: It's the rightmost of the four movement keys
The letter that comes after 'k' in the alphabet
tasks.explanation: The 'l' key moves the cursor one character to the right in normal mode.

tasks.title: Movement with Count - Down Multiple Lines
tasks.description: Move the cursor down 5 lines at once. How do you combine count with movement?
hints: Put the number before the movement command
tasks.explanation: You can prefix movement commands with a count. '5j' moves down 5 lines.

tasks.title: Word Movement - Forward
tasks.description: Move to the beginning of the next word. What command moves forward by words?
hints: Moves to the start of the next word
tasks.explanation: The 'w' command moves the cursor to the beginning of the next word.

tasks.title: Word Movement - Backward
tasks.description: Move to the beginning of the previous word. What command moves backward by words?
hints: Moves to the start of the previous word
tasks.explanation: The 'b' command moves the cursor backward to the beginning of the previous word.

tasks.title: Word Movement - End
tasks.description: Move to the end of the current or next word. What command moves to word endings?
hints: Moves to the end of the current/next word
tasks.explanation: The 'e' command moves the cursor to the end of the current word (or next word if already at the end).

tasks.title: Line Movement - Beginning
tasks.description: Move to the beginning of the current line. What command goes to line start?
hints: Think of the number that represents 'start' or 'zero'
tasks.explanation: The '0' command moves the cursor to the beginning of the current line.

tasks.title: Line Movement - End
tasks.description: Move to the end of the current line. What command goes to line end?
hints: Think of the symbol that represents 'end' in regex
tasks.explanation: The '$' command moves the cursor to the end of the current line.

tasks.title: Enter Insert Mode
tasks.description: Switch from normal mode to insert mode at the current cursor position. What key enters insert mode?
hints: This is the most basic way to start typing
tasks.explanation: The 'i' key enters insert mode at the current cursor position, allowing you to type text.

tasks.title: Insert After Cursor
tasks.description: Enter insert mode after the current cursor position (append). What key appends after cursor?
hints: Moves cursor one position right then enters insert mode
tasks.explanation: The 'a' key enters insert mode after the current cursor position (append mode).

tasks.title: Insert at Line Beginning
tasks.description: Enter insert mode at the beginning of the current line. What key inserts at line start?
hints: It's the capital version of the basic insert command
Combines going to line start and entering insert mode
tasks.explanation: The 'I' (capital I) key moves to the beginning of the line and enters insert mode.

tasks.title: Append at Line End
tasks.description: Enter insert mode at the end of the current line. What key appends at line end?
hints: It's the capital version of the append command
Combines going to line end and entering insert mode
tasks.explanation: The 'A' (capital A) key moves to the end of the line and enters insert mode.

tasks.title: Open New Line Below
tasks.description: Create a new line below the current line and enter insert mode. What command opens below?
hints: Creates a new line below and starts insert mode
tasks.explanation: The 'o' command creates a new line below the current line and enters insert mode.

tasks.title: Open New Line Above
tasks.description: Create a new line above the current line and enter insert mode. What command opens above?
hints: It's the capital version of the open command
Creates a new line above the current line
tasks.explanation: The 'O' (capital O) command creates a new line above the current line and enters insert mode.

tasks.title: Return to Normal Mode
tasks.description: Exit insert mode and return to normal mode. What key exits insert mode?
hints: Located in the top-left corner of most keyboards
tasks.explanation: The Escape key exits insert mode and returns to normal mode.

tasks.title: Delete Character
tasks.description: Delete the character under the cursor. What command deletes a single character?
hints: Think 'x' as crossing out a character
Deletes the character at cursor position
tasks.explanation: The 'x' command deletes the character under the cursor.

tasks.title: Delete Word
tasks.description: Delete from cursor to the end of the current word. What command deletes a word?
hints: Combine the delete operator with word motion
tasks.explanation: The 'dw' command deletes from the cursor to the end of the current word. This follows Vim's grammar: operator + motion.

tasks.title: Delete Entire Line
tasks.description: Delete the entire current line. What command deletes a whole line?
hints: Double the delete operator for line operations
dd is a special case of the delete operator
tasks.explanation: The 'dd' command deletes the entire current line. Doubling operators performs the action on the whole line.

tasks.title: Delete to End of Line
tasks.description: Delete from cursor to the end of the line. How do you delete to line end?
hints: Combine delete operator with end-of-line motion
tasks.explanation: The 'd$' command deletes from the cursor to the end of the line (delete + end-of-line motion).

tasks.title: Copy (Yank) Word
tasks.description: Copy the current word to clipboard. What command copies (yanks) a word?
hints: Use the yank operator with word motion
tasks.explanation: The 'yw' command yanks (copies) from cursor to the end of the current word.

tasks.title: Copy Entire Line
tasks.description: Copy the entire current line. What command copies a whole line?
hints: Double the yank operator for line operations
yy is a special case like dd
tasks.explanation: The 'yy' command yanks (copies) the entire current line.

tasks.title: Paste After Cursor
tasks.description: Paste the copied/cut text after the cursor. What command pastes after?
tasks.explanation: The 'p' command pastes the yanked or deleted text after the cursor.

tasks.title: Paste Before Cursor
tasks.description: Paste the copied/cut text before the cursor. What command pastes before?
hints: It's the capital version of paste
tasks.explanation: The 'P' (capital P) command pastes the yanked or deleted text before the cursor.

tasks.title: Change Word
tasks.description: Delete the current word and enter insert mode. What command changes a word?
hints: Use the change operator with word motion
tasks.explanation: The 'cw' command deletes the word and enters insert mode, allowing you to type a replacement.

tasks.title: Change Entire Line
tasks.description: Delete the entire line and enter insert mode. What command changes a whole line?
hints: Double the change operator for line operations
cc combines deletion and insert mode
tasks.explanation: The 'cc' command deletes the entire line and enters insert mode for replacement.

tasks.title: Undo Last Change
tasks.description: Undo the last change made to the file. What command undoes changes?
tasks.explanation: The 'u' command undoes the last change. Vim has unlimited undo levels.

tasks.title: Redo Last Undo
tasks.description: Redo the last undone change. What key combination redoes?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-r redoes the last undone change, moving forward in the undo history.

tasks.title: Repeat Last Change
tasks.description: Repeat the last change/command. What key repeats the last action?
hints: One of Vim's most powerful features
tasks.explanation: The '.' (dot) command repeats the last change. This is one of Vim's most powerful features for efficiency.

tasks.title: Find Character Forward
tasks.description: Find the next occurrence of the character 'x' on the current line. What command finds characters?
hints: Use 'f' followed by the character to find
tasks.explanation: The 'f' command followed by a character finds the next occurrence of that character on the current line.

tasks.title: Find Character Backward
tasks.description: Find the previous occurrence of the character 'a' on the current line. What command finds backward?
hints: Use capital F to search backward
tasks.explanation: The 'F' (capital F) command finds the previous occurrence of a character on the current line.

tasks.title: Go to Line Number
tasks.description: Jump to line 42 in the file. What command goes to a specific line?
tasks.explanation: The 'G' command preceded by a number jumps to that line number. '42G' goes to line 42.

tasks.title: Go to First Line
tasks.description: Jump to the first line of the file. What command goes to the beginning?
tasks.explanation: The 'gg' command jumps to the first line of the file.

tasks.title: Go to Last Line
tasks.description: Jump to the last line of the file. What single command goes to the end?
hints: Just the G command without a number
Goes to the bottom of the file
tasks.explanation: The 'G' command by itself jumps to the last line of the file.

tasks.title: Search Forward
tasks.description: Search for the word 'function' in the file going forward. What command searches forward?
hints: Use forward slash followed by the search term
Press Enter after typing the search term
tasks.explanation: The '/' command followed by a search term searches forward in the file. Press Enter to execute the search.

tasks.title: Search Backward
tasks.description: Search for the word 'class' in the file going backward. What command searches backward?
hints: Use question mark followed by the search term
Searches in the opposite direction of /
tasks.explanation: The '?' command followed by a search term searches backward in the file.

tasks.title: Next Search Match
tasks.description: Find the next occurrence of the current search term. What key goes to next match?
hints: Continues in the same direction as the original search
tasks.explanation: The 'n' command finds the next occurrence of the current search term in the same direction.

tasks.title: Previous Search Match
tasks.description: Find the previous occurrence of the current search term. What key goes to previous match?
hints: Goes opposite to the original search direction
tasks.explanation: The 'N' (capital N) command finds the previous occurrence of the search term (opposite direction).

tasks.title: Visual Mode - Character
tasks.description: Enter visual mode to select text character by character. What key starts visual mode?
hints: Allows you to select text visually
tasks.explanation: The 'v' command enters visual mode, allowing you to select text character by character.

tasks.title: Visual Mode - Line
tasks.description: Enter visual line mode to select entire lines. What key starts line visual mode?
hints: Capital V for line visual mode
Selects entire lines at a time
tasks.explanation: The 'V' (capital V) command enters visual line mode, selecting entire lines.

tasks.title: Visual Mode - Block
tasks.description: Enter visual block mode to select rectangular blocks of text. What key combination starts block mode?
hints: Control + v for block visual mode
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-v enters visual block mode, allowing you to select rectangular blocks of text.

tasks.title: Save File
tasks.description: Save the current file. What command saves the file?
tasks.explanation: The ':w' command saves (writes) the current file to disk.

tasks.title: Save and Quit
tasks.description: Save the file and exit Vim. What command saves and quits?
tasks.explanation: The ':wq' command saves the file and exits Vim (write + quit).

tasks.title: Quit Without Saving
tasks.description: Exit Vim without saving changes. What command force quits?
hints: Use quit command with exclamation mark
tasks.explanation: The ':q!' command exits Vim without saving changes. The ! forces the quit action.

tasks.title: Substitute Single Line
tasks.description: Replace the first occurrence of 'old' with 'new' on the current line. What's the basic substitute command?
tasks.explanation: The ':s/old/new/' command substitutes the first occurrence of 'old' with 'new' on the current line.

tasks.title: Substitute All on Line
tasks.description: Replace all occurrences of 'foo' with 'bar' on the current line. How do you substitute all matches?
hints: g stands for 'global' on the line
tasks.explanation: The ':s/foo/bar/g' command replaces all occurrences of 'foo' with 'bar' on the current line. The 'g' flag means global.

tasks.title: Substitute Entire File
tasks.description: Replace all occurrences of 'debug' with 'log' in the entire file. How do you substitute globally?
hints: Use % to specify the entire file
tasks.explanation: The ':%s/debug/log/g' command replaces all occurrences of 'debug' with 'log' in the entire file.

tasks.title: Join Lines
tasks.description: Join the current line with the line below it. What command joins lines?
hints: Removes the line break between lines
tasks.explanation: The 'J' command joins the current line with the line below, removing the line break.

tasks.title: Delete Inside Parentheses
tasks.description: Delete everything inside parentheses ( ). What command deletes inside parentheses?
tasks.explanation: The 'di(' command deletes everything inside parentheses using text objects (delete + inside + parentheses).

tasks.title: Delete Around Word
tasks.description: Delete the current word including surrounding whitespace. What command deletes around a word?
tasks.explanation: The 'daw' command deletes around the word, including the word and surrounding whitespace.

tasks.title: Change Inside Quotes
tasks.description: Change everything inside double quotes. What command changes inside quotes?
hints: Works with single and double quotes
tasks.explanation: The 'ci"' command changes everything inside double quotes, entering insert mode for replacement.

tasks.title: Yank Inside Braces
tasks.description: Copy everything inside curly braces { }. What command yanks inside braces?
tasks.explanation: The 'yi{' command yanks (copies) everything inside curly braces using text objects.

tasks.title: Record Macro
tasks.description: Start recording a macro in register 'a'. What command starts macro recording?
hints: Use q followed by a register letter
tasks.explanation: The 'qa' command starts recording a macro in register 'a'. Press 'q' again to stop recording.

tasks.title: Play Macro
tasks.description: Execute the macro stored in register 'a'. What command plays a macro?
hints: Use @ followed by the register letter
tasks.explanation: The '@a' command executes the macro stored in register 'a'.

tasks.title: Repeat Last Macro
tasks.description: Execute the last played macro again. What command repeats the last macro?
hints: Repeats the most recent macro execution
tasks.explanation: The '@@' command repeats the last executed macro.

tasks.title: Show Line Numbers
tasks.description: Display line numbers in Vim. What command shows line numbers?
hints: Use :set followed by the option name
number is the option for line numbers
tasks.explanation: The ':set number' command displays line numbers on the left side of the editor.

tasks.title: Enable Relative Numbers
tasks.description: Show relative line numbers (distance from current line). What command enables relative numbering?
tasks.explanation: The ':set relativenumber' command shows relative line numbers, displaying the distance from the current line.

tasks.title: Enable Syntax Highlighting
tasks.description: Turn on syntax highlighting for code files. What command enables syntax highlighting?
hints: Highlights code based on file type
tasks.explanation: The ':syntax on' command enables syntax highlighting, coloring code based on the file type.

tasks.title: Split Window Horizontally
tasks.description: Split the current window horizontally. What command creates horizontal splits?
tasks.explanation: The ':split' command splits the current window horizontally, creating two windows stacked vertically.

tasks.title: Split Window Vertically
tasks.description: Split the current window vertically. What command creates vertical splits?
tasks.explanation: The ':vsplit' command splits the current window vertically, creating two windows side by side.

tasks.title: Switch Between Windows
tasks.description: Move to the next window. What key combination switches windows?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-w w moves to the next window. Ctrl-w is the window command prefix.

tasks.title: Close Current Window
tasks.description: Close the current window. What command closes a window?
tasks.explanation: The ':close' command closes the current window. You can also use Ctrl-w c.

tasks.title: Open File in New Tab
tasks.description: Open the file 'notes.txt' in a new tab. What command opens files in tabs?
hints: Creates a new tab with the file
tasks.explanation: The ':tabnew filename' command opens a file in a new tab.

tasks.title: Next Tab
tasks.description: Switch to the next tab. What command moves to the next tab?
tasks.explanation: The ':tabnext' command switches to the next tab. You can also use 'gt'.

tasks.title: Previous Tab
tasks.description: Switch to the previous tab. What command moves to the previous tab?
tasks.explanation: The ':tabprev' command switches to the previous tab. You can also use 'gT'.

tasks.title: Global Command - Delete Lines
tasks.description: Delete all lines containing 'TODO' in the file. What global command deletes matching lines?
tasks.explanation: The ':g/TODO/d' command deletes all lines containing 'TODO'. The global command format is :g/pattern/command.

tasks.title: Global Command - Copy Lines
tasks.description: Copy all lines containing 'function' to the end of the file. What global command copies lines?
hints: t$ copies to end of file
tasks.explanation: The ':g/function/t$' command copies all lines containing 'function' to the end of the file.

tasks.title: Execute Shell Command
tasks.description: Execute the shell command 'ls -la' from within Vim. How do you run external commands?
tasks.explanation: The ':!command' format executes external shell commands from within Vim.

tasks.title: Read Command Output
tasks.description: Insert the output of 'date' command into the current file. How do you read command output?
hints: Reads command output into the file
tasks.explanation: The ':r !command' format reads the output of an external command into the current file.

tasks.title: Filter Through Command
tasks.description: Sort the current paragraph through the external 'sort' command. How do you filter text?
hints: Use ! operator with motion and command
tasks.explanation: The '!}sort' command filters the current paragraph through the external 'sort' command.

tasks.title: Increment Number
tasks.description: Increase the number under the cursor by 1. What command increments numbers?
hints: Works on numbers at or after cursor
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-a increments the number under or after the cursor by 1.

tasks.title: Decrement Number
tasks.description: Decrease the number under the cursor by 1. What command decrements numbers?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-x decrements the number under or after the cursor by 1.

tasks.title: Word Completion
tasks.description: In insert mode, complete the current word using existing words in the file. What key combination completes words?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-p in insert mode provides word completion using words that appear earlier in the file.

tasks.title: Line Completion
tasks.description: In insert mode, complete the current line using existing lines in the file. What key combination completes lines?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-x Ctrl-l in insert mode provides line completion using existing lines in the file.

tasks.title: Filename Completion
tasks.description: In insert mode, complete a filename path. What key combination completes filenames?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-x Ctrl-f in insert mode provides filename completion for paths and filenames.

tasks.title: Mark Position
tasks.description: Set a mark at the current position using mark 'a'. How do you set marks?
hints: Use m followed by a letter
tasks.explanation: The 'ma' command sets a mark 'a' at the current cursor position for quick navigation.

tasks.title: Jump to Mark
tasks.description: Jump to the position marked with 'a'. How do you jump to marks?
hints: Use single quote followed by mark letter
tasks.explanation: The ''a' command jumps to the line containing mark 'a'.

tasks.title: Jump to Mark Exact Position
tasks.description: Jump to the exact cursor position of mark 'b'. How do you jump to exact mark position?
hints: Use backtick followed by mark letter
tasks.explanation: The '`b' command jumps to the exact cursor position of mark 'b' (line and column).

tasks.title: Show Registers
tasks.description: Display the contents of all registers. What command shows registers?
hints: Shows what's stored in each register
tasks.explanation: The ':registers' command displays the contents of all Vim registers.

tasks.title: Paste from Named Register
tasks.description: Paste the contents of register 'a'. How do you paste from specific registers?
tasks.explanation: The '"ap' command pastes the contents of register 'a'. The quote accesses named registers.

tasks.title: Yank to Named Register
tasks.description: Copy the current line to register 'b'. How do you yank to specific registers?
hints: Use quote + register letter + yank command
tasks.explanation: The '"byy' command yanks the current line into register 'b'.

tasks.title: Center Screen on Cursor
tasks.description: Center the screen so the current line is in the middle. What command centers the screen?
hints: Scrolls so cursor line is centered
tasks.explanation: The 'zz' command centers the screen on the current cursor line.

tasks.title: Move Screen Top to Cursor
tasks.description: Move the current line to the top of the screen. What command moves cursor line to top?
hints: Scrolls cursor line to top of screen
tasks.explanation: The 'zt' command moves the current line to the top of the screen.

tasks.title: Move Screen Bottom to Cursor
tasks.description: Move the current line to the bottom of the screen. What command moves cursor line to bottom?
hints: Scrolls cursor line to bottom of screen
tasks.explanation: The 'zb' command moves the current line to the bottom of the screen.

tasks.title: Jump to Previous Location
tasks.description: Return to the previous cursor position. What command jumps to previous location?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-o jumps to the previous location in the jump list (older position).

tasks.title: Jump to Next Location
tasks.description: Move forward in the jump list. What command jumps to next location?
tasks.explanation: Ctrl-i jumps to the next location in the jump list (newer position).

tasks.title: Show Jump List
tasks.description: Display the jump list showing previous cursor positions. What command shows the jump list?
hints: Shows numbered list of previous positions
tasks.explanation: The ':jumps' command displays the jump list, showing numbered previous cursor positions.

tasks.title: Auto-indent Line
tasks.description: Auto-indent the current line according to file type. What command auto-indents?
tasks.explanation: The '==' command auto-indents the current line according to the file type and indentation rules.

tasks.title: Fold Create
tasks.description: Create a fold from the current line to the end of the paragraph. How do you create folds?
hints: Use zf followed by a motion
tasks.explanation: The 'zf}' command creates a fold from the current line to the end of the paragraph.

tasks.title: Fold Toggle
tasks.description: Toggle a fold open or closed at the cursor. What command toggles folds?
hints: Works on fold at cursor position
tasks.explanation: The 'za' command toggles a fold open or closed at the cursor position.

tasks.title: Open All Folds
tasks.description: Open all folds in the file. What command opens all folds?
tasks.explanation: The 'zR' command opens all folds in the file recursively.

tasks.title: Close All Folds
tasks.description: Close all folds in the file. What command closes all folds?
tasks.explanation: The 'zM' command closes all folds in the file.

tasks.title: Vim Madness Champion
tasks.description: You've completed all 100 exercises! What's the ultimate Vim philosophy?
hints: The four keys that rule them all
tasks.explanation: Congratulations! You've mastered the fundamentals of Vim. The hjkl keys represent the core philosophy of Vim: efficient, keyboard-driven editing that keeps your hands on the home row. You're now ready to customize Vim and explore advanced features!
